image.altText: Yevgeny Prigozhin is seen through an open window sitting in teh back of a black four-wheel-drive

items.synopsis: Wagner mercenary boss Yevgeny Prigozhin orders his fighters to turn back from their march towards Moscow. Follow live.

title.children: Kremlin says charges against Prigozhin will be dropped, Wagner fighters leave Rostov-on-Don

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Wagner mercenary group's march on Moscow has revived an old fear for Washington: what happens to Russia's nuclear stockpile in the event of a domestic upheaval? While US officials have kept a close eye on the unfolding situation, they say they do not see an immediate threat to Russia's nuclear stockpile. Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Pescov said the deal that sent Wagner fighters back to their camps was aimed at avoiding confrontation and bloodshed. A US National Security Council spokesperson talked to Reuters about their assessment of the situation. " We have not seen any changes in the disposition of Russian nuclear forces," they said. "Russia has a special responsibility to maintain command, control, and custody of its nuclear forces and to ensure that no actions are taken that imperil strategic stability."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: There is no "immediate threat" to Russia's nuclear stockpile, US officials say

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Wagner mercenary chief Yevgeny Prigozhin has left the headquarters of the Southern Military District amid the group's pullout from the city of Rostov-on-Don.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Yevgeny Prigozhin leaves Rostov-on-Don

children.content: Wagner mercenary chief Yevgeny Prigozhin has left the headquarters of the Southern Military District amid the group's pullout from the city of Rostov-on-Don.

props.alt: Yevgeny Prigozhin sits in the back of a car with two people in the front of the car in military gear.

children.content: Yevgeny Prigozhin has left Rostov-on-Don
(Reuters: Alexander Ermochenko)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The regional governor says the Wagner fighters have left Rostov-on-Don and are heading back to their field camps. The heavily armed Russian mercenaries, began turning back on Saturday after advancing almost all of the way to Moscow. This has de-escalated a major challenge to President Vladimir Putin's grip on power in a move their leader and the Kremlin said would avoid bloodshed.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Regional governor says Wagner group has withdrawn from Rostov-on-Don

children.content: The regional governor says the Wagner fighters have left Rostov-on-Don and are heading back to their field camps.
The heavily armed Russian mercenaries, began turning back on Saturday after advancing almost all of the way to Moscow.
This has de-escalated a major challenge to President Vladimir Putin's grip on power in a move their leader and the Kremlin said would avoid bloodshed.

image.altText: Yevgeny Prigozhin's face is illuminated by a streetlight as he partially smiles through the window of a car, rolled down

items.synopsis: Wagner troops leave Rostov-on-Don and Yevgeny Prigozhin will move to Belarus under a deal brokered by Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko to end the mutiny.

title.children: Wagner Group retreating from Russia, leader Prigozhin to move to Belarus

image.altText: A close up of Yevgeny Prigozhin and Vladimir Putin.

items.synopsis: Russian President Vladimir Putin's decision to launch a full-scale war against Ukraine has backfired catastrophically, so much so that it may end up leading to his downfall, writes Steve Cannane.

title.children: Putin has never looked so vulnerable, and it's due to his own creations

image.altText: Dougal, Madeleine and the appraiser Caroline Jones look closely at the club.

items.synopsis: For keen collectors, estate beneficiaries, and garage sale-seekers, it was an offer too good to refuse — a "no fee, no obligation" expert appraisal of their treasures.

title.children: As the cost of living rises, some Australians are holding onto antiques as a safety net while others are selling off collectibles

image.altText: A person in a hi-vis vest and white hard hat walks alongside a port with a golden retriever sniffing dog besides them

items.synopsis: Follow the path cocaine takes from Colombian bush labs to your local suburbs — and the battle to intercept it.

title.children: 'Nobody pretends we check every container': The uphill battle to keep coke out

image.altText: A composite image of two Facebook ads, run by the Yes and No Voice campaigns.

items.synopsis: Both sides of the Voice to Parliament referendum campaign are starting to spend big on social media advertising, and where they’re directing their dollars gives us some clues about their strategies, writes Casey Briggs.

title.children: The Voice No campaign has spied a path to victory, and it hangs on Australia's smallest states

image.altText: A portrait of Mandy looking into the camera. Her van is behind her. The back is open. Many items are inside.

items.synopsis: The rise in homelessness is easy to see across Australia, with more rough sleepers on streets and tent cities in parks. But there's a group experiencing homelessness who prefer to go unnoticed — the growing number of people living in vehicles.

title.children: 'Van life' is glamorised on social media. Here's the reality for one woman whose car is now home

image.altText: A man and a woman in brightly coloured vests stand outside a pink building talking at sunset

items.synopsis: In the 12 months since the US Supreme Court overturned the law enshrining abortion rights nationwide, the landscape has drastically changed. Abortion is now prohibited or heavily restricted for millions of Americans, and providers are worried their most vulnerable patients will continue to suffer.

title.children: Abortion access has virtually disappeared in parts of the US. Neither side is giving up the fight

image.altText: A man walking cattle through dusty yards

items.synopsis: An intense herd rebuild has left Australia with more cattle for market, and graziers and consumers alike are set to benefit.

title.children: Cheaper steaks on the way as more meat heads to market

image.altText: A young woman standing in the historical monument in Yogyakarta, capital city of the Central Java province.

items.synopsis: For these Australians, studying abroad opened their eyes to the colour and complexity of life in a close neighbouring country.

title.children: Maya had 'the best six months' of her life in Indonesia, but it wasn't in Bali

image.altText: A swimmer in the ocean looks out at a large opening in a rock wall.

items.synopsis: Attracting more than a million visitors each year, the Kiama Blowhole is the biggest in the world but most only see it from the top. Ex-navy officer and ocean swimmer Scott Gutterson heads underneath to document what it's like inside the blowhole's chamber.

title.children: Inside Kiama Blowhole's secret underground chamber

image.altText: A blonde white woman wearing a white and black striped singlet sits in a warmly-lit bar swilling a cocktail.

items.synopsis: After a two-year hiatus from screen acting, Lawrence is back with her characteristic blend of goof and charm in this delicious comedy inspired by a bonkers real-life dating-meets-job ad.

title.children: Jennifer Lawrence latest movie proves that the sex comedy of 2023 is a very different beast

image.altText: A woman in a brown shirt and floral skirt sits on some stairs with a typewriter

items.synopsis: When both people in a relationship are writers, creative space is a fault line. So are matters such as who looks after the kids, inspiration turf wars, and jealousy about success. Still, it's often the wives who ultimately choose writing over wedded bliss, writes Kerrie Davies.

title.children: Two writers, two careers, one relationship: Inside the literary couples where success was shared — and not equally

image.altText: Woman wearing a patterned blue dress and red glasses smiles, with her hands together. Tropical trees are in the background.

items.synopsis: As international students struggle to find accommodation, more Australians than ever before are renting out their spare bedrooms — and it's helping pay the bills.

title.children: 'If you've got a spare bedroom, you can turn it into tax-free income': More Australians hosting international students

image.altText: A man stands beside a broken-down vehicle with a big yellow sign on the side saying 'help' in black letters.

items.synopsis: Australia's stunning landscapes can be perilous for the unprepared. Two outdoor experts and an intrepid hiker give their tips for surviving in the alps, the outback and the tropics.

title.children: Why a 'MacGyver kit' could stop a camping emergency from becoming a tragedy

image.altText: A woman in a blue tracksuit lies curled up on the floor with her eyes closed surrounded by toys and building blocks

items.synopsis: But don't start petitioning your boss for a regular afternoon siesta just yet.

title.children: Regular daytime naps could be key to a healthy aging brain, new study suggests

image.altText: Pedestrian walks past Reserve Bank building in Sydney

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank says it needs unemployment to rise to bring inflation down, and we should welcome their plain speaking, writes Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: The Reserve Bank wants more unemployment. It should be applauded for admitting it

image.altText: A girl crouches towards the road after police pull over a vehicle and demand the occupants get out on the ground

items.synopsis: Criminologists and academics say some members of community Facebook groups, fed up with crime rates, are endorsing vigilante action and stirring racial tensions in regional towns.

title.children: Voice vote could be swayed by keyboard warriors inciting vigilantes and racism, say academics

image.altText: An Australian tennis player leans back ready to punch the air in celebration after winning a match in London.

items.synopsis: Alex de Minaur enjoys one of the best wins of his career to forge into the final of the prestigious Queen's Club Championship in London.

title.children: Alex De Minaur powers into Queen's Club Championship final, will face Carlos Alcaraz for title

image.altText: An aerial shot of a development plan for Little Bay near the coast in NSW

items.synopsis: The email exchange between Harry Triguboff and senior New South Wales government figures provides a glimpse into the tactics the billionaire used to try and rezone an area around Little Bay.

title.children: Emails show how billionaire tried to fast-track rezoning of Sydney precinct as angry locals fight plans

image.altText: A woman standing outside holding a black and white cat that is wearing a bib.

items.synopsis: Experts say roaming pet cats are killings millions of native wildlife annually but there is a tool to help mitigate this.

title.children: Cat bibs are being trialled to stop pets killing wildlife, but keeping cats indoors is still best

image.altText: Nick Kyrgios gives side-eye while wearing all black at a press conference.

items.synopsis: 2022 Wimbledon finalist Nick Kyrgios has pulled out of another grass-court warm-up event, leaving his prospects of a big run at the grand slam looking bleak.

title.children: Wimbledon fears for Nick Kyrgios after Mallorca withdrawal

image.altText: A homeless man sits on a blanket on a footpath wearing a hoodie.

items.synopsis: More than half the people released from Risdon Prison this year will be exiting into some form of homelessness — with more than half of those ending up back behind bars.

title.children: Prisoners released into homelessness, ending up back in jail

image.altText: A white woman with curly brown hair and glasses, stands at her front door

items.synopsis: A trip to the doctor or hospital can be a traumatic experience for trans and gender diverse people, with one in two patients reporting a negative experience. Some GPs and medical students are trying to change that.

title.children: Transgender woman Rosie avoids going to hospital when she is in mental health crisis because of discrimination

image.altText: A lady with a ventilator sits at a computer while looking at the camera

items.synopsis: Blogger and wheelchair user Amy Evans says she faced discrimination when trying to arrange tickets for the superstar's Australian performance at the MCG.

title.children: Taylor Swift concert ticketing process risks 'completely excluding' some from public spaces

image.altText: A woman wearing a jacket smiling

items.synopsis: Alison Howes is part of the growing number of Australians setting up clothing exchanges, helping people cut costs as well as reducing waste.

title.children: What's old is new again with clothing exchanges back in vogue as families look to stretch budgets

image.altText: A woman in a parliamentary committee, yelling across the room

items.synopsis: It's been a busy two weeks in Northern Territory parliament, with ministers and their departments coming under scrutiny. Here are the key takeaways.

title.children: Shouting, laughing and questions over integrity: The key moments from NT estimates

image.altText: The back of a small dog looking out a small plane window.

items.synopsis: More than 20,000 pets fly in and out of Australia each year, most in the cargo hold of commercial aircraft. But as demand grows for pets to fly in style alongside their owners, a new service is taking off.

title.children: Jet-set pets: The people spending a fortune flying fur babies around the world in charter planes
